subject: aesthetic of QS applied to RPN--Reverse Polish Notation
msgSnippet: For those of you who create fonts or are comfortable with caligraphy:  I do love the beauty of QS.  And, as Read promised, here is QS fascination for your
messageBody:
For those of you who create fonts or are comfortable with caligraphy:  I do love the beauty of QS.  And, as Read promised, here is QS fascination for your leisure hours.


Seeing what QS does for English words, I then started to wonder about reform in mathematical notation.  I'm sure that a number of you--especially those with HP calculators--have encountered RPN as an alternative for Arabic/Greek notation.  <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_Polish_notation>


RPN is wonderful stuff.  However . . . it is just so dry looking.  Any thoughts on sprucing up RPN so that look of thought that Arabic/Greek has in spades?  In other words, is there something that can do for numbers what QS does for words?


Ben
